However, after 1979, his fatwa "formed the basis for a national policy" and perhaps in part because of a penal code that "allows for the execution of homosexuals", as of 2005 Iran "permits and partly finances seven times as many gender reassignment operation as the entire [[European Union]]".{{cite book|last1=Kadri|first1=Sadakat|title=Heaven on Earth: A Journey Through Shari'a Law from the Deserts of Ancient Arabia ...|date=2012|publisher=Macmillan|isbn=9780099523277|page=251|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ztCRZOhJ10wC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Heaven+on+Earth:+A+Journey+Through+Shari%27a+Law&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAWoVChMIob7syrnZxwIVhg6SCh0fYg3Z#v=onepage&q=Heaven%20on%20Earth%3A%20A%20Journey%20Through%20Shari'a%20Law&f=false|}}{{cite news|last1=Tait|first1=Robert |title=A fatwa for freedom |agency=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2005/jul/27/gayrights.iran |date=27 July 2005 |accessdate=2 December 2015}} ==Appearance and habits== Khomeini was described as "slim", but athletic and "heavily boned".{{cite book|last1=Taheri|first1=Amir|title=The spirit of Allah: Khomeini and the Islamic revolution|date=1986|publisher=Adler & Adler|location=Bethesda, Md.|isbn=9780917561047|edition=1st U.S}} He was known for his punctuality: {{quote|He's so punctual that if he doesn't turn up for lunch at exactly ten past everyone will get worried, because his work is regulated in such a way that he turned up for lunch at exactly that time every day. He goes to bed exactly on time. He eats exactly on time. And he wakes up exactly on time. He changes his cloak every time he comes back from the mosque.According to a daughter quoted in ''In the Name of God'' by Robin Wright, 1989, p.45}} Khomeini was also known for his aloofness and austere demeanor. He is said to have had "variously inspired admiration, awe, and fear from those around him."Brumberg, ''Reinventing Khomeini'' (2001), p.53 His practice of moving "through the halls of the madresehs never smiling at anybody or anything; his practice of ignoring his audience while he taught, contributed to his charisma."Mackay, ''Iranians'' (198?) p.224 Khomeini adhered to traditional beliefs of [[Islamic hygienical jurisprudence]] holding that things like urine, excrement, blood, wine etc. and also non-Muslims were some of eleven ritualistically "impure" things that physical contact with which while wet required ritual washing or [[Ghusl]] before prayer or [[salat]].fatwa No. 83 from ''A Clarification of Questions : An Unabridged Translation of ''Resaleh Towzih al-Masael,'' by Ayatollah Syed Ruhollah Moosavi Khomeini, Translated by J. Borujerdi, with a Foreword by Michael M. J. Fischer and Mehdi Abedi, Westview Press/ Boulder and London c1984, p.48.Mottahedeh, Roy, ''The Mantle of the Prophet: Religion and Politics in Iran'', One World, Oxford, 1985, 2000, p.383 He is reported to have refused to eat or drink in a restaurant unless he knew for sure the waiter was a Muslim.Personal communications from Dr. Mansur Farhang, a biographer and supporter of Khomeini who was the former Iranian representative at the United Nations, with Ervand Abrahamian. Quoted in Abrahamian, Ervand, ''Khomeinism : Essays on the Islamic Republic'' University of California Press, (1993) ==Mystique== Khomeini was noted by many for his mystique. Before the revolution he benefited from the widespread circulation of a [[Hadith]] attributed to the Imam [[Musa al-Kazim]] who is said to have prophesied shortly before his death in 799 that: {{quote|A man will come out from [[Qom]] and he will summon people to the right path. There will rally to him people resembling pieces of iron, not to be shaken by violent winds, unsparing and relying on God(Mackay ''Iranians'', p.277. Source: Quoted in Fouad Ajami, ''The Vanished Imam: Musa al Sadr and the Shia of Lebanon'' (Ithaca: Cornell University Press, 1986), p.25}} Khomeini was the first and only Iranian cleric to be addressed as "Imam", a title hitherto reserved in Iran for the [[Imamah (Shi'a twelver doctrine)|twelve infallible leaders]] of the early Shi'a.Moin, ''Khomeini'' (2000), p.201 He was also associated with the ''[[Muhammad al-Mahdi|Mahdi]]'' or 12th Imam of Shia belief in a number of ways. One of his titles was ''Na'eb-e Imam'' (Deputy to the [[Twelfth Imam]]). His enemies were often attacked as ''[[taghut]]'' and ''[[Mofsed-e-filarz]]'' (corrupters of the earth), religious terms used for enemies of the Twelfth Imam. Many of the officials of the overthrown Shah's government executed by Revolutionary Courts were convicted of "fighting against the Twelfth Imam". When a deputy in the [[Majlis of Iran|majlis]] asked Khomeini directly if he was the 'promised Mahdi', Khomeini did not answer, "astutely" neither confirming nor denying the title.Nasr, Vali, ''The Shia Revival'', Norton, (2006), p.131 [[File:بچه و خمینی.JPG|thumb|right|Khomeini and a child.]] As the revolution gained momentum, even some non-supporters exhibited awe, called him "magnificently clear-minded, single-minded and unswerving."Harney, ''The Priest and the King'' (1998) pp. 173–4 His image was as "absolute, wise, and indispensable leader of the nation"Benard/Khalilzad, ''The Government of God'', 1984, p. 121
The Imam, it was generally believed, had shown by his uncanny sweep to power, that he knew how to act in ways which others could not begin to understand. His timing was extraordinary, and his insight into the motivation of others, those around him as well as his enemies, could not be explained as ordinary knowledge. This emergent belief in Khomeini as a divinely guided figure was carefully fostered by the clerics who supported him and spoke up for him in front of the people.Moin ''Khomeini'', (2000), p. 297
Even many [[secularist]]s who firmly disapproved of his policies were said to feel the power of his "messianic" appeal.Wright, ''In the Name of God'', (1989) (p.21-22) Comparing him to a father figure who retains the enduring loyalty even of children he disapproves of, journalist [[Afshin Molavi]] writes that defenses of Khomeini are "heard in the most unlikely settings": {{quote|A whiskey-drinking professor told an American journalist that Khomeini brought pride back to Iranians. A women's rights activist told me that Khomeini was not the problem; it was his conservative allies who had directed him wrongly. A nationalist war veteran, who held Iran's ruling clerics in contempt, carried with him a picture of 'the Imam'.Molavi, ''The Soul of Iran'', (2005), p. 256}} Another journalist tells the story of listening to bitter criticism of the regime by an Iranian who tells her of his wish for his son to leave the country and who "repeatedly" makes the point "that life had been better" under the Shah. When his complaint is interrupted by news that "the Imam" — over 85 years old at the time — might be dying, the critic becomes "ashen faced" and speechless, pronouncing "this is terrible for my country."''In the Name of God: The Khomeini Decade'' by Robin Wright c 1989, pp. 21–22 An example of Khomeini's charisma is the effect a half-hour-long, 1982 speech on the Quran by him had on a [[Muslim]] Scholar from South Africa, [[Ahmad Deedat|Sheikh Ahmad Deedat]]: {{quote|... And the electric effect he had on everybody, his charisma, was amazing. You just look at the man and tears come down your cheek. You just look at him and you get tears. I never saw a more handsome old man in my life, no picture, no video, no TV could do justice to this man, the handsomest old man I ever saw in my life was this man.{{cite web|url=http://www.inminds.com/unity.html|title=Sunni-Shia Unity, A lecture by Sheikh Ahmad Deedat|publisher=inminds.com|accessdate=6 April 2012}}}} Among some non-Muslim supporters, Khomeini made a different but also favorable impression. Before Khomeini's coming to power, American academic and activist [[Richard A. Falk]] wrote that, "the depiction of him [Khomeini] as fanatical, reactionary and the bearer of crude prejudices seems certainly and happily false".Eli Lake, [http://www.nysun.com/news/foreign/un-official-calls-study-neocons-role-911 "U.N. Official Calls for Study Of Neocons' Role in 9/11"], ''[[The New York Sun]]'', April 10, 2008 Furthermore, Khomeini's "entourage was uniformly composed of moderate, progressive individuals,"Gary Sick, ''All fall down: America's fateful encounter in Iran'', I.B.Tauris, 1985, [https://www.google.com/search?tbm=bks&tbo=1&q=All+fall+down%3A+America%27s+fateful+encounter+in+Iran+By+Gary+Sick+%22richard+falk%22+khomeini&btnG=Search+Books&safe=active p. 166]. and that "having created a new model of popular revolution based, for the most part, on nonviolent tactics, Iran may yet provide us with a desperately-needed model of humane governance for a third-world country."{{cite web|url=https://online.wsj.com/public/resources/documents/gloview021511.pdf|title=Trusting Khomeini|date=February 16, 1979|publisher=The New York Times|format=pdf |accessdate=March 26, 2011}} ==Family and descendants== {{main|Khomeini Family}} {{multiple image |align=right |direction=vertical |width=200 |image1=خمینی و نوه‌ها.JPG |caption1=Khomeini with son ([[Ahmad Khomeini|Ahmad]]) and grandsons ([[Hassan Khomeini|Hassan]] and Yaser) |image2= |caption2=Khomeini with [[Family|grandson]] and [[granddaughter]] }} In 1929,{{cite web|url=http://www.imam-khomeini.ir/|title=Imam Khomeini Official Website | سایت امام خمینی |publisher=Imam-khomeini.ir|date= |accessdate=9 March 2012}} Khomeini married [[Khadijeh Saqafi]],Taheri, ''The Spirit of Allah'' (1985), p. 90-1 the 16-year-old daughter of a cleric in [[Tehran]]. By all accounts their marriage was harmonious and happy. She died in 2009.[https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5ikwGcpqo0p2JwanEHkViYsOE0s2QD9739J480 ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090326113740/https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5ikwGcpqo0p2JwanEHkViYsOE0s2QD9739J480 |date=26 March 2009 }} They had seven children, though only five survived infancy. His daughters all married into either merchant or clerical families, and both his sons entered into religious life. [[Mostafa Khomeini|Mostafa]], the elder son, died in 1977 while in exile in [[Najaf]], Iraq with his father and was rumored by supporters of his father to have been murdered by [[SAVAK]].Moin, ''Khomeini'', (2001), 184–5 [[Ahmad Khomeini]], who died in 1995 at the age of 50, was also rumoured to be a victim of foul play, but at the hands of the regime.{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/love-the-revolution-shame-about-reality-1585085.html |title=Love the revolution, shame about reality |work=The Independent |date=5 June 1995 |accessdate=19 March 2010 | location=London | first=Robert | last=Fisk}} Perhaps his "most prominent daughter",[http://www.tnr.com/politics/story.html?id=4e1625b7-77b2-4e48-b912-55838bd983d3 "Khamenei vs. Khomeini" by Ali Reza Eshraghi], 20 August 2009. Retrieved 23 August 2009. [[Zahra Mostafavi]], is a professor at the University of Tehran, and still alive. Khomeini's fifteen grandchildren include: * [[Zahra Eshraghi]], granddaughter, married to [[Mohammad Reza Khatami]], head of the [[Islamic Iran Participation Front]], the main [[Iranian reform movement|reformist]] party in the country, and is considered a pro-reform character herself. * [[Hassan Khomeini]], Khomeini's elder grandson [[Sayid]] Hasan Khomeini, son of the Seyyed [[Ahmad Khomeini]], is a cleric and the trustee of the [[Mausoleum of Khomeini]] and also has shown support for the [[Iranian reform movement|reform movement]] in Iran,[http://www.ftd.de/karriere_management/business_english/:Business-English-Grandchildren-of-the-revolution/481985.html Grandchildren of the revolution. By von Najmeh Bozorgmehr and Roula Khalaf 04.03.2009] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090505165822/http://www.ftd.de/karriere_management/business_english/:Business-English-Grandchildren-of-the-revolution/481985.html |date=5 May 2009 }}. Retrieved 23 August 2009. and [[Mir-Hossein Mousavi]]'s call to [[2009 Iranian election protests|cancel]] the 2009 election results. * [[Husain Khomeini]] (Sayid Husain Khomeini), Khomeini's other grandson, son of Sayid Mustafa Khomeini, is a mid-level cleric who is strongly against the system of the [[Islamic Republic]]. In 2003, he was quoted as saying: "Iranians need freedom now, and if they can only achieve it with American interference I think they would welcome it. As an Iranian, I would welcome it.""Make Iran Next, Says Ayatollah's Grandson", Jamie Wilson, 10 August 2003, ''The Observer'' In that same year Husain Khomeini visited the United States, where he met figures such as [[Reza Pahlavi, Crown Prince of Iran|Reza Pahlavi]], the son of the last Shah and the pretender to the [[Sun Throne]]. Later that year, Husain returned to Iran after receiving an urgent message from his grandmother. According to [[Michael Ledeen]], quoting "family sources", he was blackmailed into returning.{{cite web |last=Ledeen |first=Michael A. |url=http://www.aei.org/publications/pubID.19680,filter.all/pub_detail.asp |title=Veiled Threats Lure Ayatollah's Grandson Home By Michael A. Ledeen, 6 January 2004 |publisher=Aei.org |date=6 January 2004 |accessdate=19 March 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090424185149/http://www.aei.org/publications/pubID.19680,filter.all/pub_detail.asp |archivedate=24 April 2009 |df=dmy-all }} In 2006, he called for an American invasion and overthrow of the Islamic Republic, telling Al-Arabiyah television station viewers, "If you were a prisoner, what would you do? I want someone to break the prison [doors open].{{cite news|author=PHILIP SHERWELL Published: 12:01 am BST 18 June 2006 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/06/18/wiran18.xml |title=Ayatollah's grandson calls for US overthrow of Iran, By PHILIP SHERWELL 19 June 2006 |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=18 June 2006 |accessdate=19 March 2010 | location=London}} * Another of Khomeini's grandchildren, Ali Eshraghi, was disqualified from the 2008 parliamentary elections on grounds of being insufficiently loyal to the principles of the Islamic revolution, but later reinstated.{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/7243383.stm |title=Khomeini grandson returns to poll, 13 February 2008 |publisher=BBC News |date=13 February 2008 |accessdate=19 March 2010}} ==Influence== On the thirteenth anniversary of Ayatollah Khomeini's death, [[Hezbollah]]'s [[Hassan Nasrallah|Nasrollah]] presented a lecture on significance the Khomeini to international. He drew parallels between Khomeini's revolution struggles and suffering and those of the Lebanon resistance factions and the Palestinian intifada and resistance. In particular, Khomeini's tactics, and particularly his steadfastness and intelligence, had greater relevance because Khomeini's movement was not a political one severed from its roots or a Jihadi revival movement disconnected from ideology, but a movement that rested on a very solid base. The domestic struggle between Ayatollah Khomeini and the Pahlavi regime was far less important, than that the Shah was an agent and instrument of the United States.{{cite book|author=Ellen Khouri|title=voice of Hezbollah: the statements of Sayyed hasan Nasrollah|year=2002|pages=267–268}} ==Bibliography == Khomeini was a prolific writer and speaker (200 of his books are online){{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/104312.stm |title=World: Middle East Ayatollah Khomeini on the Web |publisher=BBC News |date=1 June 1998 |accessdate=19 March 2010}} who authored [[Tafsir|commentaries]] on the [[Qur'an]], on [[Fiqh|Islamic jurisprudence]], [[Usul al-fiqh|the roots of Islamic law]], and [[hadith|Islamic traditions]]. He also released books about [[kalam|philosophy]], [[gnosticism]], poetry, literature, government and politics.{{cite web |url=http://www.imamreza.net/eng/imamreza.php?id=2037 |title=The Works and {{Infobox criminal | name = Samuel Little | image = | image_size = | caption = | alt = | birth_name = | alias = Samuel McDowell | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1940|06|07}} | birth_place = [[Reynolds, Georgia]], United States | death_date = | death_place = | cause = | conviction = [[Murder]] | sentence = [[Life imprisonment]] | victims = 34–90{{cite news |title=ViCAP Links Murders to Prolific Serial Killer |url=https://www.fbi.gov/news/stories/vicap-links-murders-to-prolific-serial-killer-112718 |access-date=29 November 2018 |publisher=[[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] |date=November 27, 2018 |language=en-us}} | beginyear = 1970–82 | endyear = 1989–2005 | country = United States | states = [[California]] (convicted)
13 others (accused) | apprehended = September 5, 2012 | imprisoned = [[California State Prison, Los Angeles County]] }} '''Samuel Little''' (born June 7, 1940) is an [[United States|American]] [[serial killer]]. In 2014, he was charged with the murder of three women in [[California]] between 1987 and 1989. After this conviction, California authorities said that he might have killed people in nine states from 1982 onwards. He claims to have killed as many as 90 people; investigators claim to have linked him to at least 34 murders.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/26/us/samuel-little-serial-killer-murderer.html|title=He Says He Got Away With 90 Murders. Now He’s Confessing to Them All.|last=Williams|first=Timothy|date=2018-11-26|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=2018-11-27|language=en}} == Biography == Little was born on June 7, 1940, in [[Reynolds, Georgia]], possibly during one of his mother's prison stints. Little has claimed his mother was a "[[Prostitution|lady of the night]]."{{cite news |last1=Williams |first1=Timothy |title=He Says He Got Away With 90 Murders. Now He’s Confessing to Them All. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/26/us/samuel-little-serial-killer-murderer.html |access-date=27 November 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 26, 2018 |language=en}} Soon after his birth, his family moved to [[Ohio]]. He grew up in [[Lorain, Ohio|Lorain]] and was brought up mainly by his grandmother. He attended [[Lorain City School District|Hawthorne Junior High School]], where he had problems with discipline and achievement.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/04/suspect_who_grew_up_in_lorain.html|title=Sam Little, who grew up in Lorain, is linked to serial killer probes |date=8 April 2013 |author=John Caniglia |newspaper=[[The Plain Dealer]]}} In 1956, while still a high school student, Little was arrested for the first time and convicted for breaking and entering into property in [[Omaha, Nebraska]]. He was held in an institution for juvenile offenders.{{Cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2013/04/07/timeline-retraces-whereabouts-career-criminal-alleged-serial-killer.html|title=Timeline retraces the whereabouts of a career criminal, alleged serial killer |date= 7 April 2013 |publisher=Associated Press |via=Fox News}} In the late 1960s, Little moved to [[Florida]], where he lived with his mother. He worked as an ambulance attendant and then a cemetery worker. Having a strong physique, Little took up [[boxing]] during prison time and considered himself a prizefighter at one point.{{Cite web|url=http://www.staradvertiser.com/breaking-news/more-cases-connected-to-l-a-serial-killer-suspect/ |title=More cases connected to L.A. serial killer suspect |author=Tami Abdollah |date=7 April 2013| newspaper=[[Honolulu Star-Advertiser]]}} Little did not continue his education after high school, spending most of his free time on the streets, engaging in petty theft and occasionally working part time as a [[day labor]]er. == Crimes == Little was arrested in 1961 and sentenced to three years in prison for breaking into a furniture store in Lorain. He was released in 1964. He left Ohio and shuttled between different states for the following few years and made a living through robbery and theft. By 1975, Little had been arrested 26 times in 11 states for crimes including theft, assault, attempted rape, fraud and attacks on government officials.{{Cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2013/04/07/timeline-retraces-whereabouts-career-criminal-alleged-serial-killer.html|title=Timeline retraces the whereabouts of a career criminal, alleged serial killer |date=7 April 2013 |publisher=Associated Press |via=Fox News}} Little spent much of his time with [[Prostitution|prostitutes]] and [[Procuring (prostitution)|pimps]]. In 1982 he was arrested in [[Pascagoula, Mississippi]], and charged with the murder of 22-year-old prostitute Melinda LaPree, who had gone missing in September that year. A [[grand jury]] declined to indict Little for the murder of LaPree. But while under investigation Little was transferred to Florida to be brought to trial for the murder of 26-year-old Patricia Mount, whose body was found in the fall of 1982. Prosecution witnesses identified Little in court as a person who spent time with Mount on the night before her disappearance. Due to mistrust of witness testimonies, Little was acquitted in January 1984 of Mount's murder. Little then moved to California, where he stayed in the vicinity of [[San Diego]].{{Cite web|url=https://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2013/01/suspect-1980s-slayings-arrested.html|title=Exclusive: LAPD arrests serial killer suspect from 1980s. January 07, 2013.}} In October 1984, Little was arrested for attacking and beating two prostitutes and was sentenced to 2.5 years in prison. He was released in February 1987 and soon moved to [[Los Angeles]], where he committed several murders.{{Cite web|url=http://touch.latimes.com/#section/-1/article/p2p-81233791/|title=Women's testimony called 'blueprint' to serial killer suspect's behavior |date=1 September 2014}} Little was arrested on September 5, 2012, at a [[homeless shelter]] in [[Louisville, Kentucky]], after authorities used [[Genealogical DNA test|DNA testing]] to establish that he was involved in the murder of Carol Elford, killed on July 13, 1987; Audrey Nelson, killed on August 14, 1989; and Guadalupe Abodacha, killed on September 3, 1987. All three women were killed and later found on the streets of Los Angeles. Little was extradited to Los Angeles, where he was charged on January 7, 2013.{{Cite web|url=http://lapdonline.org/newsroom/news_view/52723|title=Man Linked to Three Cold Case Murders. Monday, January 7, 2013}} A few months later, the police said that Little was being investigated for involvement in dozens of murders committed in the 1980s, which until then had been undisclosed. In connection with the new circumstances in the state of Mississippi, the case of the murder of LaPree was reopened, in which Little was acquitted in 1984.{{Cite web|url=http://www.thehollywoodgossip.com/2013/04/cross-country-killer-samuel-little-tied-to-cold-case-murders-in/|title=Cross-Country Killer: Samuel Little Tied to Cold Case Murders in 10 States? at April 8, 2013}} In total, Little was tested for involvement in 60 murders of women committed in the territory of many US states.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gainesville.com/news/20130402/local-records-chief-hailed-for-helping-crack-nationwide-cold-case|title=man suspected of killing dozens of women across the United States over the course of decades |date=2 April 2013}} == Trial and incarceration == The trial of Samuel Little for the murders of Elford, Nelson and Abodacha began in September 2014. The prosecution presented the DNA testing results as well as testimony of witnesses who were attacked by the accused at different times throughout his criminal career.{{Cite web|url=http://touch.latimes.com/#section/-1/article/p2p-81233791/|title=Women's testimony called 'blueprint' to serial killer suspect's behavior |date=1 September 2014}}{{Cite web|url=http://blog.gulflive.com/mississippi-press-news/2014/09/former_pascagoula_prostitutes.html|title=Former Pascagoula prostitutes testify of escapes from convicted serial killer Samuel Little. on September 04, 2014}} On September 25, 2014, Little was found guilty and was sentenced to [[life imprisonment]] without possibility of [[parole]]. On the day of the verdict, Little continued to insist on his innocence.{{Cite web|url=http://touch.latimes.com/#section/-1/article/p2p-81486828/l|title=L.A. serial killer gets 3 life terms, screams, 'I didn't do it!' |date=25 September 2014}} As of 2016, Little was serving a sentence at the [[California State Prison, Los Angeles County]].{{Cite web|url=http://inmatelocator.cdcr.ca.gov/Results.aspx|title=LITTLE, SAMUEL - AV2258 - 76 - 11/24/2014 - Lancaster}} ===Later confessions=== On November 9, 2018, Little confessed to the 1996 fatal strangulation of Melissa Thomas.{{cite news |title=Arrest made in 1996 murder of Opelousas woman |url=https://katc.com/news/2018/11/14/arrest-made-in-1996-murder-of-opelousas-woman/ |access-date=14 November 2018 |work=KATC.com |date=14 November 2018}} On November 13, 2018, Little was charged with the 1994 murder of Denise Christie Brothers in [[Odessa, Texas]], after having confessed the crime to a [[Texas Ranger Division|Texas Ranger]] in May 2018.{{cite news |last1=Rojas |first1=Nicole |title=Killer Samuel Little Charged in 1994 Texas Cold Case |url=https://www.msn.com/en-nz/news/world/killer-samuel-little-charged-in-1994-texas-cold-case/ar-BBPIDyL |access-date=14 November 2018 |work=www.msn.com |date=November 14, 2018 |language=en-NZ}} The [[Ector County, Texas]] District Attorney and [[Wise County, Texas|Wise County]] Sheriff's Office also announced on November 13 that Little had confessed to dozens of murders and may have committed more than 90 across 14 states between 1970 and 2005.{{cite news |last1=Fieldstadt |first1=Elisha |title=Suspected serial killer Samuel Little may be connected to at least 90 murders |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/suspected-serial-killer-samuel-little-connected-least-90-murders-n936316 |access-date=14 November 2018 |publisher=[[NBC News]] |date=November 14, 2018}}{{cite news |last1=Williams |first1=Timothy |title=He Says He Got Away With 90 Murders. Now He's Confessing Them All |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/26/us/samuel-little-serial-killer-murderer.html |access-date=26 November 2018 |work=New York Times |date=November 26, 2018}} On November 15, 2018, the [[Russell County, Alabama]] District Attorney announced that Little had earlier that month confessed to the 1979 murder of 23-year-old Brenda Alexander whose body was found in [[Phenix City, Alabama|Phenix City]].{{cite news |last1=Williams |first1=Chuck |title=Almost 40 years after Phenix City murder, California serial killer makes a confession |url=https://www.ledger-enquirer.com/news/local/crime/article221293070.html |access-date=20 November 2018 |work=[[Ledger-Enquirer]] |date=November 15, 2018 |language=en}} On November 16, 2018, [[Macon, Georgia]] sheriffs announced that Little had credibly confessed to the 1977 strangling murder of an unidentified woman and the 1982 strangling murder of 18-year-old Fredonia Smith.{{cite news |last1=Kovac Jr. |first1=Joe |title=Skeletal remains of slain Macon women linked to suspected Georgia-born serial killer |url=https://www.macon.com/news/local/crime/article221781500.html |access-date=20 November 2018 |work=[[The Telegraph (Macon)|The Telegraph]] |date=November 16, 2018 |language=en}} In the fall of 2018, Little confessed to [[Louisiana State Police]] the 1982 murder of 55-year-old Dorothy Richards and the 1996 murder of 40-year-old Daisy McGuire; both of their bodies were found in [[Houma, Louisiana]].{{cite news |title=Mass murderer implicated in 3 Louisiana deaths confesses to 90 killings spanning 4 decades |url=https://www.theadvocate.com/baton_rouge/news/crime_police/article_495ef8fc-e925-11e8-bada-5747bc629971.html |access-date=20 November 2018 |work=[[The Advocate (Louisiana)|The Advocate]] |date=November 15, 2018 |language=en}} On November 19, 2018, [[Harrison County, Mississippi]] sheriff Troy Peterson said that Little had confessed to strangling 36-year-old Julia Critchfield in the [[Gulfport–Biloxi metropolitan area|Gulfport area]] in 1978 and dumping her body off a cliff.{{cite news |last1=Fitzgerald |first1=Robin |title=She was strangled, thrown in a Coast dirt pit in 1978. Now a suspected serial killer has confessed. |url=https://www.sunherald.com/news/local/crime/article221899555.html |access-date=21 November 2018 |work=[[Sun Herald]] |date=November 19, 2018 |language=en}} On November 20, 2018, [[Lee County, Mississippi]] law enforcement officials announced that Little had admitted to killing 46-year-old Nancy Carol Stevens in [[Tupelo, Mississippi|Tupelo]] in 2005 and that the case would be presented to a grand jury in January 2019.{{cite news |title=Man who confessed to 90 deaths says he killed Decatur woman in 2005 |url=https://www.decaturdaily.com/news/morgan_county/decatur/man-who-confessed-to-deaths-says-he-killed-decatur-woman/article_8cef95dd-0e0d-5b90-a6a0-6ab0e5aad8fa.html |access-date=21 November 2018 |work=[[The Decatur Daily]] |date=November 20, 2018 |language=en}} On November 21, 2018, [[Richland County, South Carolina]] authorities announced that Little had confessed to murdering 19-year-old Evelyn Weston whose body was found near [[Fort Jackson (South Carolina)|Fort Jackson]] in 1978.{{cite news |last1=Bland |first1=David Travis |title=Serial killer likely murdered Columbia woman in 1978, sheriff says |url=https://www.thestate.com/news/local/article222013245.html |access-date=21 November 2018 |work=[[The State (newspaper)|The State]] |date=November 21, 2018 |language=en}} Little also confessed to having killed 20-year-old Rosie Hill in [[Marion County, Florida]], in 1982. On November 27, 2018, the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] announced that a [[Violent Criminal Apprehension Program]] team had confirmed 34 of Little's confessions and was working to match the remainder of Little's confessions to known murders or suspicious deaths. Little began making the confessions in exchange for a transfer out of the [[Los Angeles County, California|Los Angeles County]] prison in which he was being held.{{cite news |last1=Levenson |first1=Eric |last2=Johnston |first2=Chuck |title=A convicted murderer says he killed 90 people and got away with it. The FBI believes him. |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/11/28/us/samuel-little-serial-killer-deadliest/index.html |access-date=29 November 2018 |work=CNN |publisher=Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. |date=28 November 2018 |quote=In all, Little confessed to about 90 murders in that interview and in others, according to the Texas Rangers and the FBI.}} One included his confession to a previous cold case homicide in [[Prince George's County, Maryland]], previously one of only two homicide cases in the county with unidentified victims.{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/public-safety/serial-killer-samuel-little-says-a-1972-unsolved-maryland-case-is-among-90-he-got-away-with-police-say/2018/11/28/0f4497e2-f336-11e8-bc79-68604ed88993_story.html?utm_term=.baa6f4eba7f5|title=Serial killer Samuel Little says a 1972 unsolved Maryland case is among 90 he got away with, police say|last=Bui|first=Lynh|date=November 29, 2018|website=[[The Washington Post]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] released a list of previously unsolved murders and a map of their locations that Little attributed to himself.{{Cite web|url=https://www.fbi.gov/news/stories/vicap-links-murders-to-prolific-serial-killer-112718|title=Convicted Killer Linked to 90 Murders: FBI’s Violent Criminal Apprehension Program Connects Cases to Prolific Serial Killer|last=|first=|date=November 27, 2018|website=Federal Bureau of Investigation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} == See also == * [[List of serial killers by number of victims]] * [[List of serial killers in the United States]] == References == {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Little, Samuel}} [[Category:1940 births]] {{notability|date=June 2018}} {{in-universe|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox comics character| image= |caption=Sat-Yr-9. Art by Alan Davis |character_name=Sat-Yr-9 |real_name=Opul Lun Sat-Yr-9 |species=[[Mutant (Marvel Comics)|Human Mutant]] |publisher=[[Marvel Comics]]/[[Marvel UK]] |debut='''(UK)''' ''Captain Britain Monthly'' #3 (1984)
'''(US)''' ''[[Excalibur (comic book)|Excalibur]]'' #3 (1988) |creators=[[Alan Davis]] |alliances=[[Hellfire Club (comics)|Hellfire Club]] |aliases=Courtney Ross, White Queen |powers=channel psychic power through her eyes that force those of weak wills to submit to her every desire }} '''Opul Lun Sat-Yr-9''' (also spelled '''Sat-Yr-nin''') is a fictional character, a [[supervillain]] appearing in [[American comic book]]s published by [[Marvel Comics]]. ==Publication history== {{expand-section|date=April 2014}} Sat-Yr-9 first appeared in the UK title ''Captain Britain Monthly'' #3 (1984), and was created by [[Alan Davis]]. Her first US appearance was in ''[[Excalibur (comic book)|Excalibur]]'' #3 (1988). ==Fictional character biography== ===Dictator=== Opul Lun Sat-Yr-9 is the [[dictator]] of Earth-794, along with her lover [[Kaptain Briton]]. When he flees to [[Earth-616]] where he has an identical looking counterpart ([[Earth-616]]'s [[Captain Britain]]), she sends armored troops to retrieve him. They mistakenly attack Captain Britain twice, but are repelled on each occasion. Sat-Yr-9 hires the interdimensional mercenary group, the [[Technet (comics)|Technet]], but Briton swaps places with Britain, and the Technet take the wrong man back to Earth-794.''Captain Britain'' Vol. 2 #2 Britain later convinces the Technet of their error. When Sat-Yr-9 tries to stop them departing with Britain, the Technet slaughter her soldiers; the already psychotic Sat-Yr-9 becomes completely unhinged.''Captain Britain'' Vol. 2 #6 She kills her subjects, leading [[Roma (comics)|Roma]] to send [[Captain UK]] on a mission to overthrow and imprison her.''Captain Britain'' Vol. 2 #14 While Britain is on Earth-794, Briton is killed by [[Psylocke|Betsy Braddock]] when he tries to rape her.Captain Britain vol. 2 #7 ===Courtney Ross=== [[Image:CourtneySatyr9.PNG|Sat-Yr-9 kills Courtney Ross to take her place. Art by [[Alan Davis]].|thumb|left]] Escaping to Earth-616 through a dimensional gateway that had been opened by [[Widget (comics)|Widget]], Sat-Yr-9 kills her alternate reality counterpart, a businesswoman named [[Courtney Ross]] (and Captain Britain's ex-girlfriend), and takes her place.''Excalibur'' #4 As Ross, she tries to create a rift between Captain Britain and his current girlfriend [[Meggan]]. Sat-Yr-9 knows about [[Jamie Braddock]]'s reality warping powers before anyone else (including Jamie himself), since she has already encountered Jamie's alternate reality counterpart. Sat-Yr-9 challenges Ross's coworker (and secret admirer) Nigel Frobisher to a high-stakes card game at the London [[Hellfire Club (comics)|Hellfire Club]], and wins. Frobisher agrees to serve her, and she orders him to rescue the Earth-616 Jamie Braddock from Doc Croc, intending to use his powers as a living weapon against her adversaries.''Excalibur'' #9, 11 Sat-Yr-9 takes [[Kitty Pryde]] under her guidance,''Excalibur'' #21 enrolling Kitty in the St. Searle's School for Young Ladies, and arranges a deal to save St. Searle's from bankruptcy.''Excalibur'' #32, 34 Sat-Yr-9 uses Jamie's powers to change Frobisher into a duplicate of the female criminal [[Vixen (Marvel Comics)|Vixen]], while changing the real Vixen into a fox. With Frobisher replacing Vixen, Sat-Yr-9 takes over the Vixen's crime syndicate.{{Issue|date=April 2009}} Her powerbase built, Sat-Yr-9 attacks [[Excalibur (comics)|Excalibur]], revealing her true identity to them. She tries to enslave Captain Britain (with the implication she [[Male_rape#Female-on-male_rape|rapes]] him while he is under her mind control), against Frobisher's advice. Frobisher, already humiliated by Sat-Yr-9's treatment of him, rebels, but is killed by her. Excalibur defeats Jamie, and Sat-Yr-9 and her troops are forced to flee.{{Issue|date=April 2009}} Captain Britain swears to avenge Courtney's death, but is unable to track down Sat-Yr-9. ===Hellfire Club=== After the events of [[House of M]], Sat-Yr-9 returns. Still posing as the Earth-616 Courtney Ross, she has joined the [[Hellfire Club (comics)|Hellfire Club]] as its White Queen, with [[Viper (Madame Hydra)|Viper]], a former HYDRA assassin, as her self-proclaimed "White Princess" and bodyguard. She tries to convince Captain Britain that she is the real Courtney Ross. Captain Britain remains unconvinced, but has not moved against her. ==Other versions== *Another version of the character is [[Saturnyne]], the Omniversal Majestrix of [[Otherworld (Marvel Comics)|Otherworld]] and a servant of Roma. {{issue|date=July 2018}} *An alternate version of Sat-Yr-9 appears in ''[[Paradise X]]: Heralds'', where she displays the power to control men through pheromones. The regular Sat-Yr-9 never displayed this ability. This version is called Saturnyne, despite her appearance being that of Sat-Yr-9.{{issue|date=July 2018}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Captain Britain}} [[Category:Female supervillains]] [[Category:Fictional dictators]] [[Category:Fictional murderers]] [[Category:Fictional rapists]] [[Category:Marvel Comics telepaths]] [[Category:Marvel Comics supervillains]] [[Category:Marvel UK characters]] [[Category:Characters created by Alan Davis]] [[Category:Comics characters introduced in 1988]]

{{EngvarB|date=March 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Sorcha MacMahon | other_names = Sorcha Rogers | image = Sorcha_MacMahon.jpg
| imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = Sarah Teresa MacMahon | birth_date = 20 July 1888 | birth_place = Coas, [[County Monaghan]], Ireland | death_date = 13 December 1970 | death_place =Sutton, County Dublin, Ireland | nationality = Irish }} '''Sorcha MacMahon''' (20 July 1888 – 13 December 1970) was an Irish nationalist and [[Irish republicanism|republican]] who was active during the [[Easter Rising]] of 1916 and both the [[Irish War of Independence|War of Independence]] and the [[Irish Civil War]].
==Early life== She was born Sarah Teresa MacMahon to James and Sarah MacMahon of Coas, [[County Monaghan]] in 1888. She was one of four boys and three girls. She used the Irish form of her name, Sorcha. [[Irish Language|Irish]] was the family's first language. She was educated in Laggan National School and St Louis School in Monaghan. After school she went to [[Dublin]] and took a commercial course. She then worked as a bookkeeper for Taggart's Garage.<ref name="irishexaminer">{{cite web|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/viewpoints/analysis/seven-women-who-played-a-key-part-in-1916-and-beyond-impacting-on-society-383228.html|title=Seven women who played a key part in 1916 and beyond, impacting on society|author=Sinead McCoole}}</ref>
==Easter Rising== An early member of [[Cumann na mBan]], in 1914 MacMahon was the local secretary of the Central Branch and was secretary nationally in 1916.<ref name="irishexaminer"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.historyireland.com/20th-century-contemporary-history/cumann-na-mban-by-joseph-e-a-connell-jr/|title=Cumann na mBan by Joseph E.A. Connell Jr}}</ref> She also trained the other women in the branch in first aid and nursing as well as related branch duties. She was on the executive committee for Cumann na mBan from 1915 to 1919. She was an organiser for the [[O'Donovan Rossa]] funeral, a mass demonstration arranged when the body of the [[Fenian]] was returned from America for burial. MacMahon was selected by [[Kathleen Clarke]] as one of the women to deliver messages around Ireland for leading up to the [[Easter Rising]]. Once the Rising began MacMahon delivered the mobilisation orders to the Cumann section leaders and also delivered guns, both hidden in her bicycle basket. She continued to act as courier throughout the Rising, moving between garrisons, such as the [[Four Courts]], all week. She was estimated to have made more than 50 trips out of the [[General Post Office, Dublin#History|General Post Office]].<ref name="irishexaminer"/><ref name="McCoole2014"/><ref name="Litton2014">{{cite book|author=Helen Litton|title=Thomas Clarke: 16Lives|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kziPAwAAQBAJ|date=2 May 2014|publisher=O'Brien Press|isbn=978-1-84717-654-7}}</ref>
==After the Rising== After the Rising she assisted Clarke with the Irish Volunteer Dependants’ Fund, running it when Clarke had to take time off due to a miscarriage, postponing her own marriage to Tom Rogers to do it. She was very involved in the work and finances of the fund<ref name="irishexaminer"/><ref name="McCoole2014">{{cite book|author=Sinead McCoole|title=Easter Widows|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=47iUAwAAQBAJ|date=9 October 2014|publisher=Transworld|isbn=978-1-4481-7103-3}}</ref><ref name="Pašeta2013">{{cite book|author=Senia Pašeta|title=Irish Nationalist Women, 1900–1918|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JNhGAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA202|date=5 December 2013|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-107-72979-7|pages=202–}}</ref><ref name="Morrow-HowellSherraden2014">{{cite book|author1=Nancy Morrow-Howell|author2=Margaret Sherraden|title=Financial Capability and Asset Holding in Later Life: A Life Course Perspective|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wY5tAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA71|date=29 December 2014|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-165126-7}}</ref> Then she began working directly for [[Michael Collins (Irish leader)|Michael Collins]]. On his instructions she resigned from Cumann na mBan when they announced they were Anti-Treaty.<ref name="irishexaminer"/> MacMahon did not publicly support either side during the civil war. Her public political activities ended on 6 December 1921. However she continued to work for Collins and hold papers for him until his death in 1922. Collins was aware that his activities would put people working for him in danger so he was concerned. MacMahon had married and moved when she did which added to her safety.

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} '''The Vines of Mendoza''' is an [[Argentine wine]] business founded in 2006 by [[Michael H. Evans|Michael Evans]] and Pablo Gimenez Riili, '''The Vines of Mendoza''' is an enterprise that sells private [[vineyard]] [[estate (land)|estates]] and distributes [[Argentine]] [[wines]]. It is located in the Uco Valley of [[Mendoza Province|Mendoza]], Argentina.<ref>[http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/argentina/090302/the-rise-argentinian-wine - The Rise of Argentine Wine. Global Post. March 2009.]</ref><ref>[http://www.investors.com/NewsAndAnalysis/Article.aspx?id=508434&Ntt=Vines+of+Mendoza Get in Position to Profit. Investors Business Daily. October 2009.]</ref>
Among the varieties produced by the estate vineyards include: [[Cabernet Franc]], [[Cabernet Sauvignon]], [[Chardonnay]], [[Grenache]], [[Malbec]], [[Merlot]], [[Mourvedre]], [[Petit Verdot]], [[Pinot noir]], [[Sauvignon blanc]], [[Syrah]], [[Tempranillo]] and [[Torrontes]]
==Acequia Wine Club== The Acequia Wine Club is a wine program that ships Argentine wines not often available outside of Argentina to participating parties in the United States and Europe.<ref>http://wineshop.vinesofmendoza.com</ref><ref>http://argentinastravel.com/2030/bewitched-by-argentinas-own-napa-valley/.Retrieved on 10-8-10.</ref>
==People== Michael Evans, CEO & Founder- Prior, he worked on the [[John Kerry]] presidential campaign, was COO of the [[Rock The Vote]] campaign, and Executive Director of [[CTIA – The Wireless Association|CTIA]]'s Wireless Foundation.<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/forbes/2010/0301/second-acts-wine-mendoza-malbec-planting-roots.html Harvesting Profits in Argentina's Wine Country. Forbes. March 2010.]</ref>
Pablo Gimenez Riili, Co-Founder- After a career in law and real estate, he opened the Gimenez Riili winery with three of his brothers.<ref>[http://www.gimenezriili.com.ar/english/lafamilia.htm - Gimenez Riili The Family].</ref> Riili comes from a long family history of winemaking with the Gimenez family has been involved in the wine industry since 1945, when his grandfather Pedro planted the first family vineyard in Maipu.<ref>Winesur.com. Perpetuum - Gimenez Riili. (10-1-10) http://winesur.com/stories/perpetuum-gimenez-riili Retrieved on 10-8-10.</ref> In 2004, he met Michael Evans and in 2006 they together co-founded a [[winemaking]] enterprise with investors in the [[Uco Valley]] called The Vines of Mendoza.<ref>By Helen Coster. (3-1-10). Harvesting Profits in Argentina's Wine Country. https://www.forbes.com/forbes/2010/0301/second-acts-wine-mendoza-malbec-planting-roots.html Forbes. Retrieved on 9-28-10.</ref>
Santiago Achaval, Consulting Winemaker- Achával’s winery in Mendoza, [[Achaval-Ferrer]], maintains four of the five highest rated wines in Argentine history, according to [[Wine Spectator]].<ref>[http://www.winespectator.com/magazine/show/id/41116 Malbec Madness. Wine Spectator. December 2009.]</ref><ref>[http://www.winespectator.com/webfeature/show/id/Argentinas-Dark-Horse_1920 Argentina's Dark Horse. Wine Spectator. January 2004.]</ref><ref>[http://www.winespectator.com/webfeature/show/id/Tasting-Highlights-Malbec-from-Argentina_2612 Tasting Highlights: Malbec From Argentina. Wine Spectator. July 2005.]</ref><ref>[http://www.winemag.com/Wine-Enthusiast-Magazine/May-2007/The-Price-of-Dirt/ The Price of Dirt. Wine Enthusiast. May 2007.]</ref> He is also Consulting Winemaker at The Vines of Mendoza.<ref>[http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/argentina/090302/the-rise-argentinian-wine - The Rise of Argentine Wine. Global Post. March 2009.]</ref>
==Brands==
The Vines of Mendoza makes [[Bespoke Collection#Recuerdo Wines|Recuerdo Wines]] for the [[Bespoke Collection]].<ref name=Humiston>{{cite web|last=Humiston|first=Courtney|title=Introducing California’s Next Big Winemaking Region…Argentina?|url=http://www.7x7.com/napa/introducing-california-s-next-big-winemaking-region-argentina|work=Napa|publisher=7x7|accessdate=20 December 2012}}</ref><ref name=Orlin2>{{cite web|last=Orlin|first=Mary|title=10 Wines For Thanksgiving -- No Pinot Or Chardonnay Allowed|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/mary-orlin/10-wines-for-thanksgiving_b_1096221.html|work=Food|publisher=Huffington Post|accessdate=20 December 2012}}</ref><ref name=wines>{{cite web|title=Winegrowing|url=http://www.recuerdowines.com/the_wines/winegrowing.php|work=The Wines|publisher=Recuerdo Wines|accessdate=20 December 2012}}</ref>

{{One source|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Tom O'Folliard | image = Tom O'Folliard circa 1875 retouched and cropped.jpg | image_size = 180px | caption = O'Folliard circa 1875 | birth_name = Thomas O. Folliard, Jr. | birth_date = 1858 | alias = Tom O'Folliard | birth_place = [[Uvalde, Texas]] | height = | death_date ={{Death date and age|1880|12|19|1858}} | death_place = Fort Sumner, New Mexico | death_cause = [[Gunshot wound]] from Sheriff [[Pat Garrett]] | resting_place = Old Fort Sumner Cemetery | resting_place_coordinates = {{Coord|34|24|13|N|104|11|37|W|region:US-NM_type:landmark|display=inline|name= Billy the Kid's Gravesite}} | occupation = Ranch hand, gunfighter, outlaw | parents = {{unbulleted list|'''Father''': Thomas O. Folliard, Sr.|'''Mother''': Sarah Cook|}} | relatives = }} '''Tom O'Folliard''' (1858 – December 19, 1880) was the best friend of outlaw William Bonney, a.k.a. [[Billy the Kid]]. Both were members of the [[Lincoln County Regulators|Regulators]] during the [[Lincoln County War]]. After the war ended, they became cattle rustlers, forming the Bonney gang with fellow outlaws [[Dave Rudabaugh]] and [[Charlie Bowdre]].
O'Folliard, a [[Texas|Texan]], was a participant in the Lincoln County War and survived the famous Five-Day Battle in Lincoln during July 1878. He is said to have been wounded by a gunshot to the shoulder while escaping from the McSween residence, which had been set on fire, with Billy and three others.
==Death== He was shot in the chest by sheriff [[Pat Garrett]] on December 19, 1880, at Fort Sumner, dying approximately 45 minutes later. He was interred at Old Fort Sumner Cemetery in a plot later shared by Bonney and [[Charlie Bowdre]].<ref>Utley, Robert M. ''Billy the Kid: A Short and Violent Life.'' p. 195. {{ISBN|0-8032-4553-X}}</ref>
==Portrayals in the media== {{unreferenced section|date=April 2015}} * O'Folliard was portrayed in the 1942 film [[Apache Trail (film)]] by [[William Lundigan]]. * In the 1954 film [[The Law vs. Billy the Kid]] O'Folliard was played by actor George Berkeley. * O'Folliard was also portrayed in the 1958 film [[The Left Handed Gun]] by [[James Best]] alongside [[Paul Newman]]'s portrayal of [[Billy The Kid]]. * [[Christopher Mitchum]] portrays O'Folliard in ''[[Chisum]]'', in the film he is friends with Billy the Kid ([[Geoffrey Deuel]]). * The Tom O'Folliard character also appeared in ''[[Pat Garrett & Billy the Kid]]'' (1973), played by screenwriter [[Rudy Wurlitzer]], although depicted inaccurately as middle-aged. * O'Folliard was portrayed in the 1990 film [[Young Guns II]] by [[Balthazar Getty]] as a 14-year-old "tenderfoot" orphan from Pennsylvania who begs his way into Billy the Kid's gang. This was inaccurate, as O'Folliard was a Texan, never left the southwest and was in his late teens when he joined the Regulators. * O'Folliard was not depicted in the original [[Young Guns (film)|Young Guns]] film, although in real life he had been present for the majority of the events depicted in the movie and had been one of Billy the Kid's best friends since the two first met.

Constantino López (b. 2010)
Benedicto López (b. 2012)
Francesca Icardi (b. 2015)
Isabella Icardi (b. 2016) }} '''Wanda Nara''' (born 10 December 1986){{cite news|url=http://www.clarin.com/extrashow/fama/wanda-nara-reloj-brazalete-cartier-valor_0_1264074021.html|title=¿Cuánto valen las joyas que Wanda lleva en su muñeca?|work=[[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)|Clarín]]|accessdate=27 July 2015}} is an Argentine [[media personality]], football agent and the sister of [[Zaira Nara]]. ==Biography== ===Career=== Wanda Nara (sister of the model and TV host [[Zaira Nara]]) debuted on stage as a second ''[[vedette (entertainer)|vedette]]'' in the summer theater season of 2005–2006 in the [[revue]] ''Humor en Custodia''. Wanda in the summer theater season of 2006–2007 was a ''vedette'' in the revue ''King Corona'' of [[Jorge Corona]]: however, Wanda left the revue after two months due to alleged abuse from the comedian and his wife. In 2007 Wanda signed a contract with [[Showmatch]]'s ''Patinando por un Sueño'', and in 2009 she participated in ''[[El Musical de tus Sueños]]''. Wanda in 2011 participated in ''Patinando 2011'', a contest she left to go to [[Italy]] with her husband ([[Maxi López]] at that time) and because of her pregnancy. Wanda in September 2018{{cite web|url=http://www.sportmediaset.mediaset.it/superhomepage/varie/mediaset-wanda-nara-opinionista-a-tiki-taka_1231183-201802a.shtml|title=Mediaset: Wanda Nara opinionista a Tiki Taka - Sportmediaset|website=Sportmediaset.it}} debuted in the [[Italian television]] because{{cite web|url=http://www.corrieredellosport.it/news/social/2018/08/15-46414032/wanda_nara_a_tiki_taka_lesordio_in_tv_a_settembre/?cookieAccept|title=Wanda Nara a Tiki Taka: l'esordio in tv a settembre|publisher=}} she replaced [[Melissa Satta]]{{cite web|url=http://tvzap.kataweb.it/news/235129/wanda-nara-a-tiki-taka-opinionista-tv-mauro-icardi/|title=Wanda Nara a Tiki Taka: sarà opinionista tv|date=17 August 2018|publisher=}} as showgirl in the sports talk show of [[Italia 1]] (hosted by [[Pierluigi Pardo]]){{cite web|url=https://www.ilmessaggero.it/societa/gossip/wanda_nara_culo_tette_san_siro_instagram_20_agosto_2018-3923485.html|title=Wanda Nara fa impazzire i tifosi. E sullo sfondo c'è San Siro|publisher=}} ''[[Tiki Taka - Il calcio è il nostro gioco]]''. ===Personal life=== Nara was married to [[U.C. Sampdoria|Sampdoria]] [[Association football|footballer]] [[Maxi López]] from 28 May 2008{{cite web|url=http://www.derf.com.ar/despachos.asp?cod_des=201061&ID_Seccion=17|title=Se casó Wanda Nara - Agencia de Noticias DERF|first=Agencia|last=DERF|website=Agencia de Noticias DERF}}{{cite web|url=http://www.perfil.com/contenidos/2008/05/23/noticia_0029.html|title=Wanda Nara se casó con Maxi López|date=31 October 2018|publisher=}} to 6 November 2013;{{cite web|url=http://www.gazzetta.it/Calcio/Squadre/Catania/09-11-2013/wanda-nara-scarica-maxi-lopez-via-twitter-argentina-colpa-un-flirt-icardi-201530542460.shtml|title=Wanda Nara scarica Maxi Lopez via Twitter|publisher=|accessdate=22 August 2016}} Nara and López divorced after López accused Nara of cheating on him, but Nara accused Maxi López of repeated marital infidelity and the Argentine magistrates ruled in favor of Nara.{{cite web|url=http://www.gazzetta.it/Calcio/Serie-A/11-02-2014/wanda-nara-non-ho-mai-tradito-maxi-lui-invece-ha-avuto-tante-donne-8045265847.shtml|title=Wanda Nara: "Non ho mai tradito Maxi. Lui invece anche con la governante"|publisher=|accessdate=22 August 2016}} López and Nara have three sons, Valentino Gastón López (born 25 January 2009), Constantino López (born 18 December 2010) and Benedicto López (born 20 February 2012). Nara (with her sons) left Italy to return to [[Buenos Aires]] and began relationship with [[Inter Milan|Inter]] [[Association football|footballer]] [[Mauro Icardi]], whom she knew during his friendship with Maxi López. During the April 2014 [[Serie A]] match between Sampdoria and Inter, López notably refused to shake Icardi's hand, leading the press to dub the game "Wanda derby".{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2014/apr/14/maxi-lopez-sampdoria-wanda-derby-inter|title=Maxi López loses again in Sampdoria's 'Wanda Derby' against Inter|last=Bandini|first=Paolo|authorlink=Paolo Bandini|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=14 April 2014|accessdate=27 July 2015}} Nara and Icardi subsequently married on 27 May 2014, not long after the divorce of Wanda Nara from Maxi López (which was announced{{cite web|url=http://www.corrieredellosport.it/serie_a/catania/2013/11/06-340156/Wanda%20Nara%20e%20Maxi%20Lopez%20si%20separano%20dopo%206%20anni|title=Wanda Nara e Maxi Lopez si separano dopo 6 anni - Corriere dello Sport.it|publisher=|accessdate=22 August 2016}} on 6 November 2013) was finalised, with a small ceremony in [[Buenos Aires]] ([[Argentina]]){{cite news|title=Mauro Icardi marries Wanda Nara... months after Argentinian model split from his former team-mate Maxi Lopez|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2642214/Mauro-Icardi-marries-Wanda-Nara-months-Argentine-model-split-former-team-mate-Maxi-Lopez.html|publisher=[[Daily Mail]]|date=28 May 2014}} and a big wedding party on 7 June 2014. Nara and Icardi have two daughters, Francesca Icardi (born 19 January 2015){{cite web|url=http://www.gazzetta.it/Calcio/Serie-A/Inter/19-01-2015/inter-icardi-wanda-settimo-cielo-nata-francesca-100542618158.shtml|title=Inter, nata la figlia di Icardi e Wanda Nara. E lui twitta dalla sala parto|publisher=|accessdate=22 August 2016}} and Isabella Icardi (born 27 October 2016).{{cite web|url=http://www.gazzetta.it/Calcio/Serie-A/Inter/27-10-2016/icardi-nuovo-papa-nata-isabella-170629378849.shtml|title=Icardi e Wanda di nuovo genitori: è nata Isabella|publisher=}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nara, Wanda}} [[Category:1986 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Argentine female models]] [[Category:Argentine expatriates in Italy]] [[Category:People from Buenos Aires]] [[Category:Footballers' wives and girlfriends]]
